faqs.question: What does AXA Insurance UK plc Home Insurance insurance exclude?
faqs.answer:
The following are NOT covered under AXA Insurance UK plc's Home Insurance policy:

• Gradual damage, deterioration, wear and tear
• Damage arising from normal maintenance and upkeep
• Loss or damage while home is unoccupied for more than 30 days (most covers)
• Loss or damage while home is unfurnished for more than 30 days
• Mechanical or electrical breakdown or failure
• Damage caused by cleaning, maintenance, repair, dismantling or altering
• Damage by domestic animals (chewing, scratching, fouling, urinating)
• Damage by vermin or insects
• Settlement of new buildings
• Frost damage (under storm/flood)
• Damage to gates, hedges and fences (storm and subsidence)
• Coastal or river bank erosion
• Damage from faulty workmanship, defective design or materials
• Damage while property under construction or structural alteration
• Loss from failed online purchases or transactions
• Loss where payment proves counterfeit, false or fraudulent
• War, terrorism, radioactive contamination, sonic bangs
• Riot or civil commotion outside UK, Isle of Man or Channel Islands
• Reduction in market value following repair
• Confiscation by authorities
• Pollution/contamination (unless sudden and unforeseen)
• Deliberate or malicious acts by policyholder or family
• Loss or damage to virtual currencies
• Business use (except limited home office equipment)
• Vehicles or craft (with specific exceptions)
• Smoke damage arising gradually
• Damage caused by failure or lack of sealant/grout
• Loss or damage to pitch fibre drains from inherent defects
• Computer hacking, viruses, malware, contamination
• Unattended vehicle theft (unless items hidden and locked)
• Theft from unlocked hotel rooms
• Pedal cycle theft unless locked or in locked building
• Mobile phones (under entertainment equipment)
• Lottery and raffle tickets
• Plants and living creatures (most sections)
• Documents (except specific £500 cover)
• Dangerous dogs as listed under Dangerous Dogs Act 1991
• Horses, ponies, donkeys and mules
• Non-domesticated animal species
• Drones and aerial devices
• Transmission of contagious disease or virus

faqs.question: What does AXA Insurance UK plc Landlord's Buildings and Contents Insurance insurance exclude?
faqs.answer:
The following are NOT covered under AXA Insurance UK plc's Landlord's Buildings and Contents Insurance policy:

• Any loss or damage caused gradually or by wear & tear, depreciation, effects of light or atmosphere
• Mould, dry or wet rot or fungus
• Costs from normal use, maintenance and upkeep of buildings and landlord's contents

• Watercraft (e.g. windsurfers and sailboards)
• Electrically or mechanically propelled or assisted vehicles and any liability arising from them
• Accidental damage to landlord's contents by chewing, scratching, tearing, fouling or urinating by domestic animals
• Loss or damage to gates, hedges and fences caused by storm or flood
• Mechanical or electrical breakdown or failure (unless optional cover purchased)
• Damage caused by or in the process of cleaning, maintenance, repair, dismantling, restoring, altering dyeing or washing (unless optional cover purchased)
• Loss or damage caused, or allowed to be caused, deliberately, wilfully, maliciously, illegally or unlawfully by policyholder

faqs.question: What endorsements are available for AXA Insurance UK plc Home Insurance insurance?
faqs.answer:
The following endorsements can be added to AXA Insurance UK plc's Home Insurance policy:

**Contents Plus Accidental Damage Cover**
Extends standard contents cover to include accidental damage or loss to contents while in the home
Cost impact: Additional premium applies (shown in schedule)
Coverage impact: Adds accidental damage cover. Still excludes: mechanical/electrical breakdown, damage during cleaning/maintenance/repair, damage by pets, vermin, gradual causes, wear and tear, computer hacking/viruses, damage while unoccupied/unfurnished, items specifically excluded elsewhere. Also adds: accidental damage to contents in garden up to £1,000, house removal cover during professional removal to new UK/Channel Islands/Isle of Man residence

**Buildings Plus Accidental Damage Cover**
Extends standard buildings cover to include accidental damage or loss to the buildings
Cost impact: Additional premium applies (shown in schedule)
Coverage impact: Adds accidental damage to buildings. Still excludes: frost, water damage other than insured perils, vermin/insect damage, settlement/shrinkage, pet damage, mechanical/electrical breakdown, damage during alteration/extension, faulty workmanship/defective design, damage while unoccupied/unfurnished

**Personal Possessions Cover**
Covers personal effects, valuables and money belonging to you and your family anywhere in the world
Cost impact: Additional premium applies (shown in schedule with sum insured)
Coverage impact: Provides worldwide cover for personal items. Limits: £750 for money, £10,000 or sum insured (whichever lower) per unspecified item, £1,000 for theft from unattended vehicle (except pedal cycles). Excludes: vehicles/craft, business equipment, plants, living creatures, items obtained by fraudulent payment, failed online transactions, mechanical/electrical breakdown, damage during cleaning/repair, computer hacking/viruses, theft from unlocked hotel room, unattended pedal cycles unless locked, unattended vehicle unless items locked out of sight. Includes credit card liability up to £1,000

**Increased Valuables Limits**
Increases the standard limits for valuable items
Cost impact: Additional premium applies
Coverage impact: New limits shown in schedule replace standard £15,000 per item and £30,000 per claim limits

**Increased Money Limit**
Increases the standard £750 limit for money
Cost impact: Additional premium applies
Coverage impact: New money limit shown in schedule

**Increased Business Equipment Limit**
Increases the standard £5,000 business equipment limit
Cost impact: Additional premium applies
Coverage impact: New business equipment limit shown in schedule (including proportion for stock up to £500)

**Security Requirements Endorsement**
Specifies mandatory security measures (locks, alarms) that must be in place
Cost impact: May reduce premium if security enhanced, or may be required for acceptance
Coverage impact: Failure to meet security requirements may result in increased excess for theft claims or denial of claim. Requirements shown in schedule and must be complied with

**Specific Item Endorsement**
Increases limit for a specifically named valuable item beyond standard limits
Cost impact: Additional premium for each specified item
Coverage impact: Named item covered up to specified value shown in schedule

faqs.question: What endorsements are available for AXA Insurance UK plc Home Insurance insurance?
faqs.answer:
The following endorsements can be added to AXA Insurance UK plc's Home Insurance policy:

**Security Requirements**
Specifies required locks, alarm systems, or other security measures that must be in place
Cost impact: May reduce premium if installed, or endorsement added as condition of cover
Coverage impact: Failure to maintain security may result in higher theft excess or declined theft claims

**Increased Single Article Limit**
Increases the £15,000 standard limit for individual valuables/personal effects
Cost impact: Additional premium charged
Coverage impact: Allows higher value items to be fully covered

**Increased Valuables Limit**
Increases total limit for all valuables beyond standard
Cost impact: Additional premium charged based on increased value
Coverage impact: Provides higher total coverage for valuable items

**Unoccupancy/Unfurnished Restrictions**
May modify standard 60-day unoccupied/unfurnished terms
Cost impact: May increase or decrease premium depending on circumstances
Coverage impact: Changes when certain covers cease during unoccupancy

**Excess Variations**
Changes excess amounts for specific perils (e.g., higher subsidence excess, higher theft excess)
Cost impact: Usually reduces premium if excess increased
Coverage impact: Customer pays more of each claim up to excess amount

**Business Use**
May extend or restrict business equipment/use coverage
Cost impact: Additional premium if extending business cover
Coverage impact: Modifies standard business equipment exclusions/limits

**Property Type Restrictions**
Specific conditions for non-standard construction, listed buildings, etc.
Cost impact: May increase premium for higher risk properties
Coverage impact: May add exclusions or requirements for certain building types

faqs.question: What endorsements are available for AXA Insurance UK plc Home Insurance - Buildings and Contents insurance?
faqs.answer:
The following endorsements can be added to AXA Insurance UK plc's Home Insurance - Buildings and Contents policy:

**Home Assistance**
Underwritten by Inter Partner Assistance S.A. Provides up to £1,000 inc VAT for callout and temporary repairs for: plumbing issues (leaking pipes, blocked drains, leaking radiators), toilet waste pipe blockages, central heating/boiler failure, total electricity failure, pests (wasps, squirrels, rats, mice), broken/damaged windows, doors & locks presenting security risk
Cost impact: Optional add-on (premium not specified)
Coverage impact: Adds emergency home repair services. Excludes: LPG/oil/solid fuel fired systems, renewable heating, un-vented systems, boilers over 60 Kw/hr, boilers over 15 years old, replacement of external overflows/cylinders/tanks/radiators/sanitary ware, detached outbuildings & garages, unserviced boilers/heating systems, boilers beyond economical repair, pests outside main dwelling, descaling/power flushing/sludge damage, routine maintenance. Limited to 3 claims per 12 months.

**Family Legal Protection**
Provided by Arc Legal Assistance Limited (FCA 305958). Covers legal advisers' costs for: breach of contract for goods/services, personal injury compensation claims, employment tribunal/contract breach claims, nuisance/trespass actions, property damage actions, defending motoring prosecutions, defending consumer contract breach claims, HMRC Full Enquiry accountancy fees, data protection breach claims, Local Education Authority admission policy appeals
Cost impact: Optional add-on (premium not specified)
Coverage impact: Adds legal expense coverage. Excludes: claims with less than 51% prospects of success, unapproved costs, pre-inception incidents, disputes under £125 (plus VAT) for consumer claims, conflicts with other insured parties, costs covered by other insurance. Restrictions: can use own legal representative after court proceedings issued but only at standard adviser rates, 90-day qualifying period for employment claims, 180-day qualifying period for property infringement claims, responsible for costs if withdrawing without consent. Must notify within 180 days of incident.

faqs.question: What documents are needed to file a claim with AXA Insurance UK plc Home Insurance?
faqs.answer:
To file a claim with AXA Insurance UK plc's Home Insurance policy, you need:

• Policy number
• Details of the loss or damage
• Police crime reference number (for theft/malicious damage)
• Original purchase receipts
• Invoices
• Bank or credit card statements
• Instruction booklets
• Photographs
• Proof of authenticity
• Utility bills
• Pre-purchase surveys
• Plans and deeds of property
• Other documents reasonably required to prove claim and its value

faqs.question: How does AXA Insurance UK plc Home Insurance define 'accidental_damage'?
faqs.answer: Sudden, unexpected damage caused by an external force, and not caused deliberately

faqs.question: How does AXA Insurance UK plc Home Insurance define 'buildings'?
faqs.answer: The structure of the home including fixtures and fittings, oil/gas tanks, cesspits, septic tanks, swimming pools, hot tubs, ponds, fountains, tennis courts, walls, gates, fences, hedges, terraces, patios, drives, paths, artificial lawns, statues, decking, railings, gazebos, pergolas, car ports, garages (including on nearby sites), external lighting, alarm systems, surveillance equipment, solar heating, wind turbines, heat pumps, recreational toys, brick BBQs, laminated/vinyl flooring, inspection hatches and covers, outbuildings

faqs.question: How does AXA Insurance UK plc Home Insurance define 'contents'?
faqs.answer: Household goods (including tenant's fixtures/fittings/decorations), frozen foods, personal effects, office equipment, valuables, business equipment, money - belonging to you/family or for which you're legally responsible, mainly used for private purposes. EXCLUDES: vehicles/craft, living creatures, documents, lottery/raffle tickets, building structure (unless tenant's fixtures/fittings)

faqs.question: How does AXA Insurance UK plc Home Insurance define 'family'?
faqs.answer: Your spouse, domestic partner, civil partner, children, domestic staff, and any other person permanently living with you and not paying for accommodation

faqs.question: How does AXA Insurance UK plc Home Insurance define 'home'?
faqs.answer: The private residence shown in schedule including garages and outbuildings

faqs.question: How does AXA Insurance UK plc Home Insurance define 'outbuildings'?
faqs.answer: Sheds, greenhouses, summer houses, other buildings (not caravans, mobile homes, motor homes, or structures of canvas/PVC/non-rigid material) not forming part of main building

faqs.question: How does AXA Insurance UK plc Home Insurance define 'unoccupied'?
faqs.answer: Not lived in and not occupied overnight by you, family or authorised person for more than 30 consecutive days

faqs.question: How does AXA Insurance UK plc Home Insurance define 'unfurnished'?
faqs.answer: Has not contained enough furniture and furnishings for normal living purposes for more than 30 consecutive days

faqs.question: How does AXA Insurance UK plc Home Insurance define 'valuables'?
faqs.answer: Jewellery (including costume jewellery), articles of/containing gold/silver/precious metals, cameras, camera lenses, binoculars, watches, furs, paintings, other works of art, collections of stamps/coins/medals

faqs.question: How does AXA Insurance UK plc Home Insurance define 'personal_effects'?
faqs.answer: Clothes and items of personal nature likely to be worn, used or carried - e.g. portable radios/TVs, handheld games consoles, MP3 players, mobile phones, sports equipment

faqs.question: How does AXA Insurance UK plc Home Insurance define 'money'?
faqs.answer: Coins and bank notes in current use, cheques, postal orders, postage stamps (not collections), trading stamps, premium bonds, saving stamps/certificates, luncheon vouchers, money orders, travel tickets including season tickets, petrol coupons, gift vouchers/cards, phone cards, pre-booked event/entertainment tickets, electronic money cards. EXCLUDES credit cards, cheque cards, cash dispenser cards

faqs.question: How does AXA Insurance UK plc Home Insurance define 'business_equipment'?
faqs.answer: Items/equipment including computing equipment (excluding data) used mainly for business/trade/professional/employment purposes, including stock but excluding business money and documents

faqs.question: How does AXA Insurance UK plc Home Insurance define 'domestic_staff'?
faqs.answer: Person employed to carry out domestic duties associated with your home, not employed in connection with business/trade/profession/employment

faqs.question: How does AXA Insurance UK plc Home Insurance define 'vehicles_or_craft'?
faqs.answer: Electrically/mechanically propelled vehicles including plant machinery, mini diggers, fork lifts, powered transporters (e-scooters, segways), motorcycles, quad bikes; aircraft (including gliders), drones, aerial toys/models, boats, hovercraft, water craft including hand/foot propelled, sailboards, windsurfers; trailers, carts, wagons, caravans, horse boxes; parts, accessories, keys, fobs, tools, fitted electronics. EXCLUDES: domestic lawnmowers, wheelchairs, mobility scooters (used properly), surfboards, water-skis, snowboards, skis, toys, models, pedal cycles, electrically assisted pedal cycles (250W max, 15.5mph max), foot-controlled golf trolleys, portable GPS devices

faqs.question: How does AXA Insurance UK plc Home Insurance define 'storm'?
faqs.answer: Period of violent weather defined as: wind gusts at least 48 knots (55mph) OR torrential rain at least 25mm per hour OR snow at least one foot (30cms) in 24 hours OR hail of intensity causing damage to hard surfaces or breaking glass (equivalent to storm force 10 Beaufort Scale)

faqs.question: How does AXA Insurance UK plc Home Insurance define 'flood'?
faqs.answer: Invasion of the property by large volume of water caused by rapid build-up or sudden release of water from outside the buildings

faqs.question: How does AXA Insurance UK plc Home Insurance define 'subsidence'?
faqs.answer: Downward movement of the site on which buildings are situated by a cause other than settlement or the weight of buildings themselves

faqs.question: How does AXA Insurance UK plc Home Insurance define 'heave'?
faqs.answer: Upward or sideways movement of the site on which buildings are situated other than settlement, caused by swelling of ground

faqs.question: How does AXA Insurance UK plc Home Insurance define 'landslip'?
faqs.answer: Sudden movement of soil on a slope or gradual creep of slope over time other than settlement

faqs.question: How does AXA Insurance UK plc Home Insurance define 'settlement'?
faqs.answer: Natural movement of new properties in months and years after they are built - NOT COVERED

faqs.question: How does AXA Insurance UK plc Home Insurance define 'vermin'?
faqs.answer: Rats, mice, squirrels, owls, pigeons, foxes, bees, wasps, hornets

faqs.question: How does AXA Insurance UK plc Home Insurance define 'excess'?
faqs.answer: The amount you must pay as the first part of each and every claim made

faqs.question: How does AXA Insurance UK plc Home Insurance define 'period_of_insurance'?
faqs.answer: The period shown in your schedule for which premium has been paid and accepted

faqs.question: How does AXA Insurance UK plc Home Insurance define 'business_equipment'?

faqs.question: How does AXA Insurance UK plc Home Insurance define 'vermin'?

faqs.question: How does AXA Insurance UK plc Home Insurance define 'payment_card'?

faqs.question: How does AXA Insurance UK plc Home Insurance define 'identity_theft'?

faqs.question: What does 'unoccupied' mean and why does it matter?
faqs.answer: Unoccupied means not lived in and not occupied overnight by you, your family or an authorised person for more than 30 consecutive days. This matters because many covers cease or are restricted when the home is unoccupied - particularly theft, malicious damage, escape of water, and escape of oil. If planning to be away for more than 30 days, contact insurer to discuss options.
faqs.section_reference: Meanings of defined terms page 12, General exclusions, Specific cause exclusions throughout

faqs.question: Am I covered for accidental damage?
faqs.answer: Standard AXA Extra policies include LIMITED accidental damage: (Contents) entertainment equipment, mirrors, fixed glass, glass furniture tops; (Buildings) pipes, cables, sanitary ware, fixed glass in windows/doors/fanlights. For FULL accidental damage cover to contents and/or buildings, you need to purchase the optional 'Plus Accidental Damage' cover which will be shown in your schedule. Even with full accidental damage, there are exclusions including gradual damage, wear and tear, poor maintenance, mechanical breakdown, and damage during repairs/cleaning.
faqs.section_reference: Contents Cover 12-13, Buildings Cover 21-22, Contents Plus Accidental Damage Cover page 37, Buildings Plus Accidental Damage Cover page 49

faqs.question: What happens if my contents/buildings sum insured is too low?
faqs.answer: Your contents sum insured must equal 100% of the full replacement cost of all your contents as new. Your buildings sum insured must equal 100% of the full rebuilding cost (not market value). If the sum insured is less than 100% of the full value, you will only be paid up to the sum insured shown in your schedule, NOT the full cost to replace/rebuild. It's essential to regularly review and update your sum insured to ensure adequate cover.
faqs.section_reference: General Conditions page 14-15, How we settle claims pages 23-24

faqs.question: What should I do if my home will be empty for more than 30 days?
faqs.answer: Contact your insurer BEFORE the 30 day period expires. Cover for escape of water ceases after 30 days unoccupied. Theft, malicious damage, and escape of oil are also excluded while unoccupied. You must either: keep central heating on low to prevent freezing, OR drain the central heating system and turn off water at mains. Consider whether you need specialist unoccupied property insurance if absence will be prolonged.
faqs.section_reference: Important Information pages 7-8, Escape of water exclusions, Various cause exclusions throughout policy

faqs.question: Am I covered for storm damage to my fence/gate?
faqs.answer: No. Loss or damage to gates, hedges and fences is specifically excluded under storm cover. Gates, hedges and fences are only covered if damaged by other insured perils such as fire, theft, malicious damage, riot, or collision by vehicles/aircraft/animals. They are also excluded from subsidence cover unless the main building is damaged at the same time by the same cause.
faqs.section_reference: Buildings Cause 1 - Storm or flood, page 41

faqs.question: What is the difference between 'occupiers liability' and 'property owners liability'?
faqs.answer: OCCUPIERS AND PUBLIC LIABILITY (Contents section, up to £2m) covers your liability arising from OCCUPATION of the home and private pursuits - i.e. you living there and day-to-day activities. PROPERTY OWNER'S LIABILITY (Buildings section, up to £2m) covers your liability arising from OWNERSHIP of the buildings (but not occupation) and defective work on properties you've sold. If you both own and occupy your home, you need both covers. If you're a tenant, you need occupiers liability. If you're a landlord not living there, you need property owner's liability.
faqs.section_reference: Contents Cover 28 pages 33-34, Buildings Cover 19 pages 46, Important notes in both sections

faqs.question: My washing machine pipe burst and caused water damage - am I covered?
faqs.answer: Yes, this is covered under Escape of Water. The policy covers water leaking from washing machines, dishwashers, water beds, fridges and freezers. However, the excess applies. Note: damage to the washing machine itself is only covered if caused by an insured peril. The cost to repair/replace the burst pipe itself is not covered - you pay for this. The policy covers the CONSEQUENTIAL damage the escaping water caused to your home and contents. If the home has been unoccupied for more than 30 days, there is NO cover.
faqs.section_reference: Contents Cause 4 page 26, Buildings Cause 2 page 41

faqs.question: I left my bath running and it overflowed causing damage - am I covered?
faqs.answer: Not under standard cover. Damage caused by sinks and baths overflowing as a result of taps being left on is specifically excluded from the Escape of Water cover. However, IF you have purchased the optional 'Plus Accidental Damage' cover for contents and/or buildings, this type of damage may be covered under that section (subject to accidental damage exclusions and excess).
faqs.section_reference: Contents Cause 4 page 26, Buildings Cause 2 page 41, Accidental damage sections

faqs.question: Are my belongings covered when I take them outside the home?
faqs.answer: LIMITED cover under standard policy: Contents can be temporarily removed to (1) bank/safe deposit (2) other private occupied/furnished dwelling (3) place where you're working/temporarily living worldwide. Limits apply including £2,500 max for theft from student accommodation. For COMPREHENSIVE away-from-home cover, you need to purchase optional PERSONAL POSSESSIONS cover which provides worldwide cover up to the sum insured shown in your schedule. This covers items anywhere in the world but has specific exclusions (unattended vehicles, unlocked hotel rooms, etc.).
faqs.section_reference: Contents Cover 19 pages 30-31, Personal Possessions section pages 39-40

faqs.question: What is covered under 'subsidence' and what's excluded?
faqs.answer: COVERED: Downward movement of the site caused by subsidence, or upward/sideways movement caused by heave, or landslip. EXCLUDED: Settlement (natural movement of new buildings), damage to boundaries/gardens/drives/pools unless main building damaged at same time, damage due to construction/alteration/demolition, coastal or river bank erosion, damage from defective materials/design/workmanship, damage to solid floor slabs and non-loadbearing walls unless foundations beneath external walls damaged at same time. A specific excess applies (shown in schedule). These claims can be complex - report as soon as you notice cracking or movement.
faqs.section_reference: Buildings Cause 4 pages 42, Important Information page 7

faqs.question: Will you pay the full cost to replace my damaged carpet/floor covering?
faqs.answer: Only for the damaged area. If a floor covering is damaged beyond repair, the policy will only pay to replace the damaged floor covering in that room. It will NOT pay for undamaged floor covering in adjoining rooms, even if the replacement doesn't match. This is stated in the 'Matching sets, suites and carpets' section of How we settle claims.
faqs.section_reference: How we settle claims pages 23-24

faqs.question: My laptop was stolen from my car - am I covered?
faqs.answer: Depends on circumstances and what cover you have. Under CONTENTS 'Temporary Removal' cover: only covered if stolen from unattended vehicle when items were HIDDEN FROM VIEW in locked boot or glove compartment AND all doors including boot were LOCKED. If these conditions not met, no cover. Under PERSONAL POSSESSIONS cover (if purchased): max £1,000 for theft from unattended vehicle (excluding pedal cycles) and same conditions apply about items being locked out of sight. Laptops in plain view are NOT covered.
faqs.section_reference: Contents Cover 18 page 30, Contents Cover 19 page 31, Personal Possessions Cover 1 page 39

faqs.question: Does the policy cover gradual damage and wear and tear?
faqs.answer: NO. This is a key exclusion. The policy specifically excludes 'loss or damage caused gradually or by wear and tear, depreciation, effects of light or atmosphere, mould, dry or wet rot or fungus and costs that arise from the normal use, maintenance and upkeep of buildings and contents.' Home insurance covers sudden, unexpected insured events - not deterioration over time or lack of maintenance. You are required to maintain your property in good repair. Damage that would have been prevented by proper maintenance is not covered.
faqs.section_reference: General Exclusions page 19, Important Information pages 6-7, Throughout policy exclusions

faqs.question: How long do I have to report a claim?
faqs.answer: You must report claims AS SOON AS POSSIBLE. For theft or malicious damage, you must contact the Police URGENTLY and obtain a crime or lost property reference number. Unreasonable delay in reporting may prejudice your claim. If requested, you must send written details within 30 days. Any writ, summons, letter of claim or other legal document must be sent to the insurer AS SOON AS POSSIBLE. Early reporting allows insurer to investigate properly, arrange emergency action if needed, and preserve evidence.
faqs.section_reference: Claims Conditions pages 20-21, Making a claim page 22

faqs.question: Can I use my own builder/repairer or do I have to use yours?
faqs.answer: The insurer may appoint an approved supplier to validate your claim and arrange quotation, repair or replacement. Permanent repairs by approved suppliers are guaranteed. However, you have a choice: If the insurer offers repair/replacement through a preferred supplier but you choose cash settlement instead, payment will NOT EXCEED the amount the insurer would have paid the preferred supplier. This could be less than the cost of using your own builder. If no equivalent replacement is available, full replacement cost will be paid with no discount. The insurer may also repair/reinstate/replace directly or pay cash/cash alternative (including vouchers/store cards).
faqs.section_reference: How we settle claims page 23, Claims conditions page 21

faqs.question: What is the maximum buildings sum insured I can select?
faqs.answer: You can select your buildings sum insured between £50,000 and £1,000,000
faqs.section_reference: What is insured - page 1

faqs.question: What is the maximum landlord's contents sum insured?
faqs.answer: You can select your landlord's contents sum insured between £5,000 and £60,000
faqs.section_reference: What is insured - page 1

faqs.question: Am I covered if the property is empty?
faqs.answer: No, loss or damage occurring after the property has been unoccupied caused by malicious people, escape of water, escape of oil or theft is not covered
faqs.section_reference: What is not insured - page 1

faqs.question: Is damage by tenants' pets covered?
faqs.answer: No, accidental damage to landlord's contents by chewing, scratching, tearing, fouling or urinating by domestic animals is excluded
faqs.section_reference: What is not insured - page 1

faqs.question: Are fences covered for storm damage?
faqs.answer: No, loss or damage to gates, hedges and fences caused by storm or flood is specifically excluded
faqs.section_reference: What is not insured - page 1

faqs.question: How much time do I have to cancel after receiving the policy?
faqs.answer: You have 14 days from receipt of policy documents to cancel, with full refund if cover hasn't started or pro-rata refund if it has (provided no claims)
faqs.section_reference: How do I cancel the contract - page 3

faqs.question: What liability coverage is included?
faqs.answer: Property owner's liability up to £2,000,000, public liability up to £2,000,000, and employer's liability up to £10,000,000
faqs.section_reference: What is insured - page 1

faqs.question: Is alternative accommodation covered if tenants need to move out?
faqs.answer: Yes, alternative accommodation or loss of rent is covered up to 20% of the buildings sum insured
faqs.section_reference: What is insured - page 1

faqs.question: Can I get accidental damage cover?
faqs.answer: Yes, optional covers are available for additional accidental damage to both landlord's contents and buildings
faqs.section_reference: Optional covers - pages 1-2

faqs.question: How quickly must I report a Legal Expenses claim?
faqs.answer: You must notify Legal Expenses claims as soon as possible and within no more than 180 days of becoming aware of the insured incident
faqs.section_reference: What are my obligations - page 2

faqs.question: Will I get a refund if I cancel mid-term?
faqs.answer: Yes, you will receive a pro-rata refund for the unused period, provided no claims have been made. If claims have been made, no refund is provided
faqs.section_reference: How do I cancel the contract - page 3

faqs.question: What changes must I notify the insurer about?
faqs.answer: Change of address, structural alterations, if property will no longer be let, change of use, if property becomes unoccupied, bankruptcy, police cautions or criminal convictions
faqs.section_reference: What are my obligations - page 2

faqs.question: What is the difference between buildings and contents insurance?
faqs.answer: Buildings insurance covers the structure of your home including fixtures/fittings and permanent features like walls, fences, paths, garages, outbuildings. Contents insurance covers your household goods, furniture, appliances, personal belongings, and valuables inside the home and temporarily removed from it.
faqs.section_reference: Meanings of defined terms - Buildings and Contents definitions, pages 8-9

faqs.question: Am I covered for accidental damage?
faqs.answer: Yes, both buildings and contents are covered for accidental damage as standard on this AXA Advanced policy. Accidental damage means sudden, unexpected damage from an external force. However, numerous exclusions apply including wear and tear, gradual damage, poor maintenance, mechanical/electrical breakdown, damage by pets, and damage while property is unoccupied/unfurnished.
faqs.section_reference: Contents Cause 1 and Buildings Cause 1, pages 22-23 and 30

faqs.question: How long can I leave my home unoccupied?
faqs.answer: Unoccupied means not lived in or occupied overnight for more than 60 consecutive days. After 60 days, you lose cover for: malicious damage, theft, escape of water, oil leaks, accidental glass breakage. You still have cover for other perils like fire, storm, flood etc. You must notify AXA if your home will be unoccupied.
faqs.section_reference: Meanings of defined terms page 10, Contents and Buildings exclusions pages 22-23 and 30

faqs.question: Are my belongings covered when I travel abroad?
faqs.answer: Yes, your contents are covered worldwide when temporarily removed from the home. However, limits apply: £15,000 for theft from unattended vehicles, £15,000 for theft from hotel rooms, £15,000 for theft of unattended items (unless in bank/safe deposit or residence where you're working/living). Valuables left unattended outside the home have limited cover.
faqs.section_reference: Contents worldwide section, limits on page 22

faqs.question: What is subsidence and is it covered?
faqs.answer: Subsidence is downward movement of the site on which your buildings are situated (not caused by the building's weight or settlement). It is covered. However, damage to boundary walls, fences, hedges, paths, drives, swimming pools etc. is only covered if the main building is damaged at the same time. Not covered if caused by construction, defective materials, coastal erosion, or affecting only non-load-bearing walls/solid floor slabs. You should notify AXA as soon as you suspect subsidence.
faqs.section_reference: Meanings of defined terms page 10, Buildings exclusions page 30, Important information page 4

faqs.question: Does the policy cover me if I have a flood?
faqs.answer: Yes, flood damage is covered for both buildings and contents. Flood means invasion of property by large volume of water from outside the buildings. However, damage to gates, hedges, fences is excluded. Not covered if your home is unoccupied over 60 days. If you have a flood claim over £10,000 for buildings repair, AXA will also pay up to £10,000 extra to help reduce future flooding risk.
faqs.section_reference: Cause 1 coverage, Meanings of defined terms page 9, Buildings Cover 11 page 32-33

faqs.question: What should I do if I have an escape of water?
faqs.answer: Turn off the water at the mains and call the Domestic helpline (0330 024 6849) for emergency assistance, then call the claims line (0330 024 6843). AXA covers damage caused by water escaping from fixed installations, washing machines, dishwashers etc. However, the cost of repairing the source (like a worn-out pipe) is not covered - only the damage the water caused. You must keep your heating on low when away in winter or drain the system. Cover ceases if property unoccupied over 60 days.
faqs.section_reference: Important information page 4, Making a claim page 16, Contents/Buildings Cause 1

faqs.question: Are there any limits on individual valuable items?
faqs.answer: Yes, any single valuable or personal effect is limited to £15,000 unless it's specified on your schedule with a higher limit. The total for all valuables is limited to the valuables limit shown in your schedule. You should tell AXA about items worth over £15,000 so they can be specified.
faqs.section_reference: Coverage limits page 22, Meanings of defined terms page 10

faqs.question: What excess do I have to pay?
faqs.answer: You must pay the excess shown in your schedule on each and every claim. Different excesses may apply for different types of claim. If you don't meet security requirements endorsed on your policy, you may have to pay a higher theft excess. The excess is the first part of every claim that you must pay yourself.
faqs.section_reference: Meanings of defined terms page 9, General conditions page 12, Special conditions page 28

faqs.question: Can I cancel my policy?
faqs.answer: Yes. Within 14 days of receiving your documents (cooling off period), you'll get a full refund if cover hasn't started, or a pro-rata refund if it has (provided no claims). After 14 days, you can cancel anytime and get a pro-rata refund if you haven't claimed and the refund exceeds £15. If you have claimed or are claiming, you won't get a refund (or may need to continue instalments until renewal if paying monthly).
faqs.section_reference: General conditions - Cancelling the policy, pages 13-14

faqs.question: What is not covered under this policy?
faqs.answer: Main exclusions include: wear and tear, gradual damage, poor maintenance, mechanical/electrical breakdown, damage by pets, vermin, loss while unoccupied over 60 days (certain perils), theft without force, deliberate damage, business use beyond limits, vehicles/craft (with some exceptions), reduction in value (except antiques), war, terrorism (except riot), nuclear risks, pollution (except sudden events), loss from fraudulent payment, items more specifically insured elsewhere. A full list is in the exclusions sections throughout the policy.
faqs.section_reference: General exclusions pages 15, Contents exclusions pages 22-24, Buildings exclusions page 30

faqs.question: Am I covered for storm damage?
faqs.answer: Yes, storm damage is covered for buildings and contents. AXA defines storm as: wind gusts 48+ knots (55mph), OR rainfall 25mm+/hour, OR snow 30cm+ in 24 hours, OR hail damaging hard surfaces/breaking glass. However, AXA considers multiple factors when assessing storm claims, not just this definition. They'll look at whether storm conditions occurred, whether damage is consistent with storm, and whether storm was the main cause (not poor maintenance or wear and tear). Not covered for gates, hedges, fences.
faqs.section_reference: Meanings of defined terms page 10, How we settle claims - Storm damage page 20, Important information page 5

faqs.question: What is alternative accommodation cover?
faqs.answer: If your home cannot be lived in because of insured damage, AXA will pay reasonable costs for alternative accommodation for you, your family, and domestic animals for up to 3 years. They'll also pay rent you're liable for or would have received. AXA determines 'reasonable cost' based on your circumstances, your needs, how long you'll need it, and what's available locally.
faqs.section_reference: Contents Cover 4 page 24, Buildings Cover 2 pages 30-31

faqs.question: Is my bicycle covered?
faqs.answer: Yes, pedal cycles are covered as contents (including electrically assisted pedal cycles up to 250W that don't propel the bike over 15.5mph). However, if stolen while unattended, they must be in a locked building or secured by a suitable lock to a permanent structure or motor vehicle. Cycles are covered worldwide up to the contents sum insured, subject to the theft from vehicle/unattended items limits.
faqs.section_reference: Meanings of defined terms - Personal effects page 10, Vehicles or craft exclusions page 10-11, Contents Cause 1 exclusions page 23

faqs.question: What identity theft cover do I get?
faqs.answer: You get up to £50,000 cover for: legal costs defending claims from card issuers, costs to prove innocence, costs to remove wrongful judgments, costs to challenge credit reports, postal/phone costs dealing with the issue, loan reapplication fees, and lost earnings taking time off work. You must contact the Identity Theft helpline (0330 024 8687) first, then complete a claim form, file a police report, and notify your banks promptly. Claims must be made within 6 months of policy end.
faqs.section_reference: Contents Cover 24 pages 28-29

faqs.question: Am I covered if someone is injured at my property?
faqs.answer: It depends if you own or rent. If you OWN the property, you have Property Owner's Liability cover up to £5,000,000 (Buildings Cover 12). If you RENT/OCCUPY, you have Personal Liability cover up to £5,000,000 (Contents Cover 21). These cover your legal liability for death/injury or property damage to third parties. Not covered: business use, family members, employees (unless domestic staff covered separately), vehicles/craft, transmission of disease, or property in your control.
faqs.section_reference: Buildings Cover 12 page 33, Contents Cover 21 pages 27-28, Important information under Personal Liability page 27-28

faqs.question: What if I am underinsured?
faqs.answer: If your contents sum insured is less than 100% of the full replacement value of all your contents, AXA will only pay a proportionate amount of any claim. For example, if you insured for £50,000 but should have insured for £100,000 (only 50% of correct value), AXA would only pay 50% of any claim. You must notify AXA if the full value exceeds your sum insured.
faqs.section_reference: General conditions - Maximum limits page 12

faqs.question: What happens if I need to claim and I'm paying monthly?
faqs.answer: If you have claimed or are claiming and try to cancel, you won't get a refund. You'll either have to continue monthly instalments until renewal, or AXA may deduct outstanding instalments from your claim payment. If AXA cancels due to fraud, they may not refund any premium and you may have to repay already paid claims.
faqs.section_reference: General conditions - Cancelling the policy pages 13-14, Claims conditions - Fraud page 18

faqs.question: Do I need to tell you if my circumstances change?
faqs.answer: Yes, you must tell AXA as soon as reasonably possible if circumstances change. Examples include: change of address, structural alterations, letting/subletting your home, using home for business, home becoming unoccupied, home no longer occupied solely by you/family, bankruptcy, criminal convictions (except motoring). AXA will tell you if premium or terms change. Failure to notify may result in claims being refused/reduced, policy cancelled/voided, or premium/terms changed.
faqs.section_reference: General conditions page 12

faqs.question: Are my belongings covered during a house move?
faqs.answer: Yes, if using professional removal contractors. Cover includes storage for up to 60 days if part of the move, to any new private residence in UK, Channel Islands or Isle of Man. However, money is excluded, and china/glass/porcelain must be professionally packed. Jewellery and sea transit are also excluded. Mechanical/electrical breakdown not covered during transit.
faqs.section_reference: Contents Cause 3 - House removal pages 23-24

faqs.policy_type: Landlord Buildings and Contents Insurance (Buy to Let)
faqs.question: What happens if my property is empty between tenants?
faqs.answer: If the property is not lived in for 7 consecutive days or more between tenancies, you must: (a) turn off gas, electricity and water at the mains and drain the water/heating system, OR (b) maintain the property at a temperature of at least 10°C, AND (c) the premises must be visited at least once every 7 days. Cover completely ceases after the property has been unoccupied for more than 60 consecutive days.
faqs.section_reference: General Conditions, section 7 'Unoccupancy between tenancy agreements' and Definition of 'Unoccupied'
tags: landlord buildings and contents insurance (buy to let)

faqs.policy_type: Landlord Buildings and Contents Insurance (Buy to Let)
faqs.question: Am I covered if my tenant deliberately damages the property?
faqs.answer: Yes, malicious damage is covered under Cause 4 (Buildings) and Cause 4 (Landlord's Contents), subject to the policy excess. However, there is no cover while the property is unoccupied, and malicious damage caused by you (the policyholder) is excluded.
faqs.section_reference: Buildings Cause 4 - Malicious people; Landlord's Contents Cause 4 - Malicious people
tags: landlord buildings and contents insurance (buy to let)

faqs.policy_type: Landlord Buildings and Contents Insurance (Buy to Let)
faqs.question: What is the difference between Buildings standard cover and Buildings accidental damage?
faqs.answer: Buildings standard cover protects against specific named perils (causes 1-13) such as fire, flood, storm, theft, escape of water, etc. Buildings accidental damage is an optional extension that provides broader cover for sudden, unexpected damage from external forces that aren't specifically listed. However, it still has exclusions including frost, vermin, domestic animals, settlement, and damage while unoccupied.
faqs.section_reference: Buildings standard cover (pages 24-30) vs Buildings - accidental damage (page 31)
tags: landlord buildings and contents insurance (buy to let)

faqs.policy_type: Landlord Buildings and Contents Insurance (Buy to Let)
faqs.question: If my tenant's belongings are damaged, are they covered under this policy?
faqs.answer: No. This policy covers only landlord's contents (furniture, appliances and furnishings that you own as the landlord). Tenant's personal belongings are specifically excluded and the tenant would need their own contents insurance.
faqs.section_reference: Definition of 'Landlord's contents' - excludes 'Tenant's property'
tags: landlord buildings and contents insurance (buy to let)

faqs.policy_type: Landlord Buildings and Contents Insurance (Buy to Let)
faqs.question: What should I do immediately after discovering damage?
faqs.answer: (1) Take steps to prevent further damage (e.g., turn off utilities); (2) For emergencies, call the 24-hour domestic helpline 0370 646 4952 (you pay contractor costs); (3) If theft or malicious damage, urgently inform police and get crime reference number; (4) Contact AXA claims team on 0330 024 6842 as soon as possible; (5) Do NOT dispose of damaged items as they may need to be inspected; (6) Take photos and gather evidence/receipts.
faqs.section_reference: Claims Conditions pages 18-19 and Making a Claim page 20
tags: landlord buildings and contents insurance (buy to let)

faqs.policy_type: Landlord Buildings and Contents Insurance (Buy to Let)
faqs.question: Am I covered for subsidence?
faqs.answer: Yes, subsidence, ground heave and landslip are covered under Buildings Cause 5, subject to a separate subsidence excess. However, there are significant exclusions including: damage to boundary walls/fences/paths unless main building also damaged, settlement/shrinkage, damage from construction/alterations, coastal erosion, defective materials/design. You must report subsidence as soon as you notice signs (e.g., diagonal cracks).
faqs.section_reference: Buildings Cause 5 - Subsidence, ground heave or landslip, pages 24-25 and Important Information page 7
tags: landlord buildings and contents insurance (buy to let)

faqs.policy_type: Landlord Buildings and Contents Insurance (Buy to Let)
faqs.question: What if my buildings or contents sum insured is too low?
faqs.answer: If your sum insured is less than 100% of the full rebuilding cost (for buildings) or full replacement value (for contents), we will settle claims proportionately based on the percentage of premium you paid versus what you should have paid. For example, if you're insured for £600,000 but should be insured for £700,000 (you paid only 86% of correct premium), we'll pay only 86% of valid claims. You must notify AXA if values exceed your sums insured.
faqs.section_reference: General Conditions 3 'Maximum limits' pages 12-13 and How we settle claims page 21
tags: landlord buildings and contents insurance (buy to let)

faqs.policy_type: Landlord Buildings and Contents Insurance (Buy to Let)
faqs.question: Does the policy cover water damage from a burst pipe?
faqs.answer: Yes, escape of water from fixed water, drainage or heating installations is covered under Cause 6 (Buildings and Landlord's Contents). However, there is no cover while the property is unoccupied, no cover for damage caused by failure of sealant/grout, and the pipe itself is only covered if damaged by an insured cause. You pay for the pipe repair itself, but damage caused by the leaking water is covered.
faqs.section_reference: Buildings Cause 6 and Landlord's Contents Cause 6, pages 25 and 33, plus Important Information page 7
tags: landlord buildings and contents insurance (buy to let)

faqs.policy_type: Landlord Buildings and Contents Insurance (Buy to Let)
faqs.question: Am I covered if someone is injured at the property?
faqs.answer: Yes, property owner's liability (if buildings cover purchased) and public liability (if contents cover purchased) both provide £2,000,000 cover for compensation you become legally liable to pay for death/injury or property damage. This covers your legal liability as property owner or arising from landlord's contents, but excludes liability from tenant occupation, vehicle use, employee injury (covered separately under employer's liability), and deliberate acts.
faqs.section_reference: Buildings Cover 21 - Property owner's liability (pages 29-30) and Landlord's Contents Cover 16 - Public liability (pages 36-37)
tags: landlord buildings and contents insurance (buy to let)

faqs.policy_type: Landlord Buildings and Contents Insurance (Buy to Let)
faqs.question: What legal protection do I have?
faqs.answer: Legal expenses cover (up to £50,000) is included if shown on your schedule. It covers: (1) Nuisance or trespass proceedings relating to the insured property (must have started 180+ days after policy purchased); (2) Defence of criminal prosecutions under Gas Safety Regulations, Furniture Fire Safety Regulations, and Electrical Equipment Safety Regulations. You must comply with regulations and keep evidence. There's a 24/7 legal helpline (0330 024 8694) and landlord's legal document service. Legal expenses claims must be reported within 180 days.
faqs.section_reference: Legal Expenses section pages 40-46
tags: landlord buildings and contents insurance (buy to let)

faqs.policy_type: Landlord Buildings and Contents Insurance (Buy to Let)
faqs.question: Can I cancel my policy?
faqs.answer: Yes. You have 14 days from receipt of policy documents (cooling-off period) to cancel. If cover hasn't started, you get a full refund. If it has started, you get a pro-rata refund (unless claims made). After the cooling-off period, you can cancel anytime with pro-rata refund if no claims and refund exceeds £15. If paying by instalments and you've claimed, you must continue payments until renewal or outstanding amount is deducted from claim payment.
faqs.section_reference: General Conditions 9 'Cancelling the policy' pages 14-15
tags: landlord buildings and contents insurance (buy to let)

faqs.policy_type: Landlord Buildings and Contents Insurance (Buy to Let)
faqs.question: What is NOT covered under storm damage?
faqs.answer: Storm exclusions include: (1) Damage to gates, hedges and fences (buildings); (2) Storm damage to aerials/satellite dishes (buildings); (3) Property in the open (contents); (4) Damage by frost. Also, storm is strictly defined (48 knot winds OR 25mm/hour rainfall OR 30cm snow in 24 hours OR damaging hail), but AXA considers other factors beyond just the definition when assessing claims.
faqs.section_reference: Buildings Cause 2 and Landlord's Contents Cause 2, plus 'Storm damage claims' explanation on page 22 and Important Information page 8
tags: landlord buildings and contents insurance (buy to let)

faqs.policy_type: Landlord Buildings and Contents Insurance (Buy to Let)
faqs.question: What happens if I don't maintain the property properly?
faqs.answer: You must maintain the property in good repair (General Condition 4). Damage caused by gradual deterioration, wear and tear, or lack of maintenance is excluded throughout the policy (General Exclusion 9). For example, if a pipe bursts due to wear and tear, the water damage may be covered but not the pipe replacement. Poor maintenance can also result in claims being declined, particularly for storm, escape of water, and subsidence claims.
faqs.section_reference: General Condition 4 page 13, General Exclusion 9 page 17, and Important Information pages 6-8
tags: landlord buildings and contents insurance (buy to let)

faqs.policy_type: Landlord Buildings and Contents Insurance (Buy to Let)
faqs.question: How does the inflation protection work?
faqs.answer: Sums insured for buildings and landlord's contents are automatically reviewed and adjusted monthly based on official indices (House Rebuilding Cost Index for buildings, Consumer Durables RPI for contents). We won't reduce sums insured if indices fall. No extra charge until renewal, when premium is recalculated on revised sums insured. However, you should not rely solely on this - you must ensure sums insured are adequate, especially after extensions or major purchases.
faqs.section_reference: Inflation Protection section page 23
tags: landlord buildings and contents insurance (buy to let)

faqs.policy_type: Landlord Buildings and Contents Insurance (Buy to Let)
faqs.question: What should tenants do in an emergency?
faqs.answer: Tenants should: (1) Take immediate steps to prevent further damage (turn off water/gas/electricity at mains); (2) Call the 24-hour emergency helpline 0370 646 4952 for urgent tradesperson assistance (tenant/landlord pays contractor costs); (3) Do not conduct permanent repairs before inspection; (4) Inform you (the landlord) immediately so you can contact AXA claims team on 0330 024 6842. For alternative accommodation needs, AXA will discuss reasonable options considering the circumstances.
faqs.section_reference: Making a claim page 20 and Buildings Cover 15/16 pages 27-28
tags: landlord buildings and contents insurance (buy to let)

faqs.question: What is the maximum I can claim for a single valuable item?
faqs.answer: £15,000 for any one valuable or personal effect, unless the item is specifically listed on your policy, in which case the limit is £25,000
faqs.section_reference: What is insured? - page 1

faqs.question: Am I covered if my home is empty?
faqs.answer: Coverage is restricted when the home is unoccupied or unfurnished. Loss or damage caused by malicious people, theft or attempted theft, or escape of water or oil is not covered after the home has been unoccupied or unfurnished. You must notify the insurer if your home will be unoccupied.
faqs.section_reference: What is not insured? - page 1; What are my obligations? - page 3

faqs.question: Can I get a refund if I cancel my policy?
faqs.answer: Yes. Within 14 days of receiving documents: full refund if cover hasn't started, or pro-rata refund if no claims made. After 14 days: pro-rata refund as long as no claims made during coverage period. If any claims have been made, no refund is available.
faqs.section_reference: How do I cancel the contract? - pages 3-4

faqs.question: Are my contents covered when I take them abroad?
faqs.answer: Yes, contents are covered while temporarily removed anywhere in the world up to the contents sum insured
faqs.section_reference: What is insured? - page 1; Where am I covered? - page 3

faqs.question: What emergency repairs are covered under Home Assistance?
faqs.answer: Plumbing issues (leaking pipes, blocked drains, radiators), toilet blockages, central heating/boiler failure, total electricity failure, pests (wasps, squirrels, rats, mice), and broken windows/doors/locks presenting security risk. Up to £1,000 inc VAT per claim, maximum 3 claims per year. Your boiler must be serviced annually.
faqs.section_reference: Optional Covers - Home Assistance - pages 1-2

faqs.question: Is storm damage to my fence covered?
faqs.answer: No, loss or damage to gates, hedges and fences caused by storm or flood is specifically excluded
faqs.section_reference: What is not insured? - page 1

faqs.question: What if my building work causes damage?
faqs.answer: Loss or damage arising from the alteration or extension of the buildings is not covered. You must notify the insurer of any structural alterations.
faqs.section_reference: What is not insured? - page 1; What are my obligations? - page 3

faqs.question: How much business equipment is covered?
faqs.answer: Business equipment is covered up to £15,000, but identity theft connected with your business, profession or occupation is excluded
faqs.section_reference: What is insured? - page 1; What is not insured? - page 1

faqs.question: Can I choose my own solicitor for Family Legal Protection claims?
faqs.answer: Yes, once court proceedings are issued or if conflict of interest arises, but the insurer will only cover costs up to their standard advisers' rates. You must gain consent before incurring any legal advisers' costs.
faqs.section_reference: Are there any restrictions on cover? - Optional Covers - page 2

faqs.question: What happens if items are stolen from my car?
faqs.answer: Theft from vehicles or craft is only covered if all windows and doors are closed, all doors and openings are securely locked, and all reasonable precautions have been taken to conceal the items from view
faqs.section_reference: What is not insured? - page 1

faqs.policy_type: Home Insurance - Household Buildings and Contents Insurance
faqs.question: What happens if my home is left empty?
faqs.answer: Loss or damage occurring after the home has been unoccupied or unfurnished is not covered for theft, malicious people and escape of water or oil. You must notify the insurer if your home will be unoccupied.
faqs.section_reference: What is not insured - page 1
tags: home insurance - household buildings and contents insurance

faqs.policy_type: Home Insurance - Household Buildings and Contents Insurance
faqs.question: Are my belongings covered if I take them with me on holiday?
faqs.answer: Base policy includes temporary removal up to £100,000. For worldwide cover of personal possessions, you need to add the optional Personal Possessions cover which provides worldwide protection for personal effects, valuables and money.
faqs.section_reference: What is insured - Temporary removal; Optional Personal Possessions cover
tags: home insurance - household buildings and contents insurance

faqs.policy_type: Home Insurance - Household Buildings and Contents Insurance
faqs.question: What if my bath overflows because I left the taps on?
faqs.answer: This is not covered under the base policy unless you purchase the additional accidental damage to contents cover.
faqs.section_reference: What is not insured - page 1
tags: home insurance - household buildings and contents insurance

faqs.policy_type: Home Insurance - Household Buildings and Contents Insurance
faqs.question: Does the policy cover my garden fence if damaged in a storm?
faqs.answer: No, loss or damage to gates, hedges and fences caused by storm or flood is specifically excluded.
faqs.section_reference: What is not insured - page 1
tags: home insurance - household buildings and contents insurance

faqs.policy_type: Home Insurance - Household Buildings and Contents Insurance
faqs.question: Can I cancel my policy after the 14 day cooling off period?
faqs.answer: Yes, you can cancel at any time with written notice. You'll receive a pro-rata refund as long as you haven't incurred claims during the coverage period. If claims have been made, no refund is provided.
faqs.section_reference: How do I cancel the contract - page 3
tags: home insurance - household buildings and contents insurance

faqs.policy_type: Home Insurance - Household Buildings and Contents Insurance
faqs.question: Is my boiler covered if it breaks down?
faqs.answer: The base policy does not cover mechanical/electrical breakdown. However, the optional Home Assistance cover provides up to £1,000 for boiler failure callout and temporary repairs, subject to conditions including the boiler being under 15 years old and serviced within the past year.
faqs.section_reference: Optional covers - Home Assistance, page 2
tags: home insurance - household buildings and contents insurance

faqs.policy_type: Home Insurance - Household Buildings and Contents Insurance
faqs.question: What is the maximum I can claim for a single valuable item like jewelry?
faqs.answer: Any one valuable item is covered up to £15,000, with total valuables per claim up to £30,000.
faqs.section_reference: What is insured - page 1
tags: home insurance - household buildings and contents insurance

faqs.policy_type: Home Insurance - Household Buildings and Contents Insurance
faqs.question: Am I covered if I accidentally damage my TV?
faqs.answer: Yes, accidental damage to entertainment equipment is covered up to £100,000 under the base policy.
faqs.section_reference: What is insured - page 1
tags: home insurance - household buildings and contents insurance

faqs.policy_type: Home Insurance - Household Buildings and Contents Insurance
faqs.question: What if I need to stay elsewhere while my home is being repaired after damage?
faqs.answer: Alternative accommodation is covered up to £200,000 for Buildings claims and up to £15,000 for Contents claims. There's also emergency evacuation alternative accommodation up to £2,500.
faqs.section_reference: What is insured - page 1
tags: home insurance - household buildings and contents insurance

faqs.policy_type: Home Insurance - Household Buildings and Contents Insurance
faqs.question: Does wear and tear damage get covered?
faqs.answer: No, any loss or damage caused gradually or by wear and tear, depreciation, effects of light or atmosphere, mould, dry or wet rot or fungus, and costs from normal use, maintenance and upkeep are excluded.
faqs.section_reference: What is not insured - page 1
tags: home insurance - household buildings and contents insurance

faqs.policy_type: Home Insurance - Household Buildings and Contents Insurance
faqs.question: How long do I have to report a legal issue under the Family Legal Protection?
faqs.answer: You must notify claims as soon as possible once you become aware of the insured incident and within no more than 180 days of becoming aware.
faqs.section_reference: What are my obligations - Family Legal Protection, page 3
tags: home insurance - household buildings and contents insurance

faqs.policy_type: Home Insurance - Household Buildings and Contents Insurance
faqs.question: Can I use my own solicitor for a legal claim?
faqs.answer: Once court proceedings are issued or if a conflict of interest arises, you can use your own legal representative, but the insurer won't cover any costs exceeding their standard advisers' rates.
faqs.section_reference: Are there any restrictions on cover - Family Legal Protection, page 2
tags: home insurance - household buildings and contents insurance
